page.title: 12St Mary's - Colwich Abbey
page.content: The building was built by Charles Cope Trubshaw in 1742 as a home which he called Mount Pleasant. It later became a hunting lodge for Lord Tamworth and was sold after his death to a group of Benedictine Nuns in 1833, who later incorporated it into St. Benedict's Priory. There are some twenty nuns here now, under the Abbess, Dame Edith. They are an enclosed order. This particular Benedictine order was founded in Paris in 1661 and came to England some time after the French Revolution. Each of the nuns have their own room. They are self sufficient in vegetables and bake some bread. The nuns rise each day at 5.30am and usually attend chapel service seven times before lights out at 10.00pm.
